comments.text:
+Nathan Bonnell I'm sure it was a happy accident, parrots are extremely 
vocal :) It's how they communicate with their flock in the wild, and in 
captivity it's how they communicate with their owners. Also, when it comes 
time to get a bird you should look into a breeder or rescue, since pet 
stores tend to breed and socialize parrots poorly.

top_comment.text:
Where do the common budgies fit in with all of this. Are they true 
parakeets? Are they conures?

I love your videos and more than anything, I love the passion you have for 
what you do, not to mention the love and appreciation you have for all 
creatures. You and your husband are very special people.﻿
top_comment.author: ChefMimsy

comments.text:
They're parakeets. They're old world parrots, and all conures are new world 
so they can't be conures. But parakeet is just a physical description and a 
name given to parrots with long slender tails. It's not based on phylogeny.
comments.author: locolobos0035

comments.text:
They're a separate thing, I think? So, most of those conures were in 
Arinae, New World Parrots like the Macaw, but (and everything after this 
point is coming from Wikipedia) budgies are on a separate branch, in the 
same subfamily as lories and lorikeets. They are parakeets, but any parrot 
with a long, tapered tail can be considered a parakeet. It's not really a 
taxonomical term.
comments.author: False Name

comments.text:

comments.author: Youri Neeven

comments.text:
You may have been kidding but I whipped up a graph for you (link at the 
bottom of the comment). Conures are a type of new world parrot, while 
parakeet isn't technically a taxonomic classification, but usually 
describes a long-tailed parrot. 

Old world parrots cannot be conures but they can be parakeets (since 
parakeet is a physical definition, not a taxonomic one. Does that make 
sense? 

Here's a link to my graph, with the cladogram stolen from some paper 
somewhere. I got it through Google images. http://i.imgur.com/Sm7t9ba.png
comments.author: locolobos0035

top_comment.text:
I understand why Jessi has these birds as they are rescues, but please, if 
you are considering getting a bird, DONT!!! These birds are not made to be 
pets and are used to flying dozens of miles every day when in the wild. 
They just can't do that when locked up inside a house. ﻿
top_comment.author: RubikMaster13

comments.text:
+RubikMaster13 U know, that a lot of bird lover take his bird outside, and 
they come back, right? That just make ur point invalid. For me, that 
actually happened, with a magpie, i got from the neighborhood. He became a 
real friend after just a few monts, we took him outside, he flew to the 
trees, and came back to our garden. Never flew away. But we do not wanted 
to keep that bird from start, so we took it to a bird refuge to help him go 
back to a wild. Parrots are different, i live in hungary, and here is cold 
in winter. If u say, i take my parrot outside, well, its dead if it flew 
away.... And most people dont risk it with parrots. Tamed parrots cant live 
in wild, NEVER let them flew away.
comments.author: RetroShock!

comments.text:
+RetroShock! If your bird is really happy, let him go outside! He's 
amazingly happy indoors so he'll surely come back right?
comments.author: RubikMaster13

comments.text:
+RubikMaster13 Oh man, u cant just fight against it... people will always 
have tamed birds, they kept them thousands of years ago, and they will in 
the future too. I love birds, and i will alwasy keep birds. With OPEN 
cages, with so much care. And when i see, my bird is happy, it means, MY 
BIRD IS HAPPY. He just doesn't care if he born to be wild or not, if he is 
happy. Only this matters.
comments.author: RetroShock!

comments.text:
Dogs are meant to hunt in packs, cats are meant to go out and stalk prey, 
but I don't see complaining about them being kept. Parrots are social 
animals and can thrive and live very happily in environments with caring, 
and responsible owners who have done their research into how to properly 
raise their pets. They are also prey animals--they don't fly dozens of 
miles every day, they live forests and generally keep in cover due to 
predatory birds in their native habitats. Having owned a quaker parrot 
myself for many years, they are very loving companions just as much--if not 
more so--than dogs and cats.
comments.author: Rayn Sideways

comments.text:
My conure is always with me out of his cage.. Even tho I know where you are 
coming from my family and I come from Colombia and many people from my 
country have these types of birds.. We don't keep them locked up they are 
in the back yard where they are able to go where they want but they choose 
to stay there BC they know who feeds them.. That is the same way I have my 
GCC and he is happy! He loves my daughters and rides on my dogs back! I 
know its sad that there are so many breeders but at least the birds have 
good loving homes.. These types of bird would not survive here because a 
lot of them are from the tropical.. So I get you but all we can do is hope 
that all those birds find good homes!!😊
comments.author: Colombiana Makeup

comments.text:
+Minshino I agree with you.  I let my dusky conure out of his cage quite 
often and he too is happy, healthy and VERY noisy!  -LORD, is he noisy!

comments.author: Kurdt_Nirawall

comments.text: I plan to diss ingeniously.
comments.author: Roman Jones

comments.text:
+Roman Jones That's not the issue, don't be disingenuous. Birds are very 
intelligent, social creatures. Some parrot species have the intellect and 
logical capacities of human children. Many of them live close to 80 years. 
A huge number of them are poached as eggs or chicks from the wild and have 
not been domesticated. Without proper physical and environmental 
accommodations, nutrition, socialization, and intellectual stimulus, 
provided by people who understand them and their behavior, birds become 
incredibly stressed and unhealthy. They display self mutilation (such as 
pulling out their feathers or smashing their beaks into bars) and mental 
illness. They're not in *any way* comparable to fish or cats and should not 
be treated as such.
comments.author: aggrocrow

comments.text:
Going by that logic, fish should not be kept in tanks, cats should not eat 
from a can, and plants should not be kept in pots. Let's just run around 
naked throwing sharpened sticks at impalas.
comments.author: Roman Jones

comments.text:
+Roman Jones In the wild, these birds can fly  between 40-60 miles per day. 
Even a big house is no substitute... birds should not be pets.
comments.author: RubikMaster13

comments.text:
+Roman Jones I don't think you got what we're saying at all. They're not 
meant to be kept captive and the pet industry is destroying them.
comments.author: aggrocrow

comments.text:
I'm sorry you feel that way. My budgies and tiels were free-range in my 
house and were very happy, flying all over the house, playing with everyone 
all day, and finally dying of old age.
It really depends on the owner more than the animal.
comments.author: Roman Jones

comments.text:

rescues, not to purchase from breeders. Purchasing them only encourages the 
pet trade. It's a horrible situation but one that we need to make tough 
choices over a long period of time to fix. We caused this problem, so we 
need to fix it.

comments.text:
This, this, this. I only know one person (personally) whom I would consider 
qualified to own parrots, and they are her entire world. She's spent her 
whole life working for parks, rescues, and zoos, so she knows just how 
smart they are and how much care they need - and that they will probably 
outlive her.

Human love = lock you up in a cage and keep you for ever and ever!

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure that most cats can learn to get along with birds but I have 
a hunter cat. We moved to an apartment and she managed to catch a bird on 
the balcony. I think in my case it would be better not to risk a little 
bird's life.
comments.author: Bananna85

comments.text:
+Benjamin Alexander
Yes, I have cats and rats (lots of each), and from personal experience the 
rats are mor elikely to attack the cats than vice versa.
comments.author: rdizzy1

comments.text:
I don't have a lot of experience, but some of the people I know have both 
birds (100s, from chickens and pheasants to pigeons and parakeets) and 
cats.  Because cats are domesticated animals, they can learn what other 
animals belong to their owner and they can learn not to attack them.  My 
friend's experience with chickens and cats is that his cat learns 
immediately which chicks are his (and are ignored) and which are the 
neighbors (which get chased away!)

It seems like magic to me, but there are cute cat videos on youtube 
coexisting with other birds (sometimes well, sometimes not so well). 

You know your cats, and that matters more.  I just encourage you to 
consider some supervised introductions before you write off birds entirely.
comments.author: Benjamin Alexander

comments.text:
It's called "eye pinning" or "eye flashing" - parrots contract their pupils 
when they are excited, as a form of communication. It's pretty cool.

comments.text:
Take all the parrots in the world. Some of those parrots are parakeets, but 
not all are. Take all those parakeets. Some of those parakeets are conures, 
but again, not all are. Conures are a subset of parakeets which are a 
subset of parrots.

captions.text:
Welcome to Animal Wonders! Today, we're going
to meet some of our amazing animal ambassadors.

We're gonna learn about their group, we're
going to talk about why it's confusing sometimes

to classify animals, and we're going to talk
a little bit about the terms we use.

So, what do you think of when you hear the
word "conure"? If you thought "LOUD", you

are so right. But, if you didn't even hear
the word before, you're me, ten years ago.

This, is a conure! A green-cheeked conure
to be exact, or you can call her a green-cheek

parakeet. I just call her Ginger. And this
is where the complication of classifying starts.

The word "conure" is both an old term and
a new term. It's an old, out-of-date classification

for a genus of parrot-like New World birds
and it was called conurus.

"New World" just means the Americas. Now,
the previous genus conurus included some present-day

genera that has now been broken apart into
more specific groups.

Today, the term is used mostly in aviculture,
which is the keeping and breeding of birds

in captivity. And I use the term because that's
how it was first introduced to my many Central
and South American psittacine friends.

But it also helps me explain the difference
in the groups.

So, I've heard of parrots and parakeets before,
but what the heck was a conure? This [bird

squawks loudly] is a conure! This is a Jenday
conure or a Jendaya parakeet-- both terms
are correct. I call her Ecuador.

Now Jenday conures are closely related to
Sun conures and they're very popular in the
pet trade. But they are very very vocal.

Oh! I soon discovered these birds were one
of the most neglected and re-homed groups
in the animal rescue world.

The more I learned about the individual personalities
of the birds that I got to rescue, my fascination

with these overly exploited and underappreciated
group of birds grew. And the more I tried

to define what a conure was, the more complicated
it seemed to get.

So most people that see a bird with a curved
beak - you can do it-- oh! --and bright feathers
say, "That's a parrot," and they're correct.

So here's how it goes: all parrot-like birds
belong to the order Psittaciformes. But then

there are families that break them down into
smaller groups. The three main families are
Psittacidae, Psittaculidae and Cacatuidae.

The family Psittacidae includes birds like
macaws and parrots and conures and parakeets.

The family Psittaculidae includes birds like
love birds and loris and other Old World parrots.

And then the family Cacatuidae includes cockatoos
and cockatiels and others.

So what makes a conure different form a parrot?
Well they're not really different. They're

just more specific. So, this is a parrot--
[bird squeals]. This is Zoe. She's a red-lored

Amazon parrot, and you can look at her-- [bird
squawks] --and you can see that she has a

very heavy body; and her tail-- [bird says
"pretty pretty pretty pretty"] --her tail

is very squared at the bottom. Would you like
another treat? No? Ok.

But, then you look at-- [bird squawks] --at
Loulou, the half-moon conure, you can see

he has a more slender body, and his tail is
tapered or cone-shaped. And you can see a

big difference in [bird squawks] not just
their size, but the shape of their body.

So if you look at Loulou and Ecuador, and
ignore the coloration on their feathers, just

look at the characteristics on their body.
Both of them have a hooked bill, curved in

a very similar way. They have long, tapered
tails which are about the same length as their

body. They have short feet, and their toe
arrangement is zygodactyl, which is two toes

in the front and two toes in the back. And
if you look up at their eyes, they both have
a bare patch surrounding their eye.

So the group of conures are made up of quite
a few different genera. The main two are Pyrrhura

and Aratinga. These two are both in the Aratinga
genus, and Aratinga means "mini macaw."

Speaking of, this, is a macaw! This is Joy,
and she's a blue and gold macaw-- You so excited?

--now you can see she's much larger than Lulu
and Equador, but she has similar characteristics

in her body. You can see that she has almost
a slender body, and this long, tapered tail

that's pretty much the same length as her
body.

So we met three conures, a parrot, and now
a macaw. But what's the difference between

a parakeet and a conure? Well, this is a parakeet.
His name is Zapper. He's an Alexandrian parakeet,

or, an Alexandrian parrot. He can't be considered
a conure even though he has a long, tapered

tail and the slender body of a conure. He
is found in India, Thailand, and Afghanistan,

and surrounding areas. So, he's considered
an Old World parrot instead of a New World

parrot. He's also part of the family Psittaculidae,
instead of Psittacidae.

So let's meet another conure. This is Maui,
and she's a color-morph with a green-cheek

conure. She's referred to as a pineapple green-cheek
conure. Note her long, slender tail and cone

shape like that-- so she belongs to the parakeet
group --but she also lives in the New World

so she can be defined as a conure. So let's
really classify her.

Her order is Psittaciformes, her family is
Psittacidae, and then her genus is Pyrrhura,

as opposed to Aratinga, which was Lulu and
Ecuador, the other one.

Now let's make things even more fun! This
is a parrotlet. A Pacific parrotlet named

Sprinkles, and he is a parrot, but not a parakeet.
Notice his heavy body set and his tail, when

spread out, is going to look like a square,
very similar to our Amazon parrot Zoe.

And lastly, we have Boxer, the peach-faced
lovebird. He's not a conure, and he's not

a parakeet. He looks very similar to Sprinkles
the parrotlet, but he is an Old World parrot.

Very small little parrot, but he does not
belong to the family Psittacidae like Sprinkles

does, but he belongs to the family Psittaculidae,
like Zapper our Alexandrian parakeet. But,

unlike Zapper, he's not a parakeet, he's a
small parrot with a heavy body and a square
tail.

Alright guys, so to wrap this up, all conures
are parrots, but not all parrots are conures.

All conures are parakeets, but not all parakeets
are conures. And all parakeets are parrots,
but not all parrots are parakeets. Make sense?

If you have any questions about all of that
or anything else, you can find me on Twitter,

Tumblr, and Facebook. You can find out all
about animal wonders on our website, and don't

forget to subscribe to our YouTube channel
and join us on an adventure every week.
[Bird squeaks]

Hey guys! We 
had so many questions last time that we couldn't
put into one episode! So here we are making

a second episode, and this is going to be
called... Ask Jesse 1.5!

And if you have any questions you can find
me on Twitter, Tumblr and Facebook. Don't

forget to sucri- subscribe to our YouTube
channel [Laughs] and join us on an adventure
every week!
